factoid: The service was proceeding in the Cathedral of the Assumption.
The service was a combined service of prayer for the Emperor's arrival.
The service was a combined service of thanksgiving for the conclusion of peace with the Turks.
The crowd outside the Cathedral spread out.
Hawkers appeared outside the Cathedral.
The hawkers were selling kvass.
The hawkers were selling gingerbread.
The hawkers were selling poppyseed sweets.
Pétya was particularly fond of poppyseed sweets.
Ordinary conversation could be heard outside the Cathedral.
A tradesman's wife was showing a rent in her shawl.
A tradesman's wife was telling how much the shawl had cost.
Another tradesman's wife was saying that all silk goods had now gotten dear.
The clerk who rescued Pétya was talking to a functionary.
The clerk who rescued Pétya was talking about the priests officiating that day with the bishop.
The clerk used the word "plenary" several times.
Pétya did not understand the word "plenary".
Two young citizens were joking with some serf girls.
The serf girls were cracking nuts.
All conversations might have had a particular charm for Pétya at his age.
The conversations did not interest Pétya now.
Pétya sat on the pedestal of the cannon.
Pétya was still agitated by the thought of the Emperor.
Pétya was still agitated by his love for the Emperor.
Pétya had experienced pain and fear when he was being crushed.
Pétya had experienced rapture when he was being crushed.
The feeling of pain and fear intensified Pétya's sense of the importance of the occasion.
The feeling of rapture intensified Pétya's sense of the importance of the occasion.
The sound of a cannon firing was heard from the embankment.
The cannon firing was to celebrate the signing of peace with the Turks.
The crowd rushed impetuously toward the embankment to watch the cannon firing.
Pétya would have run to the embankment.
The clerk who took the young gentleman under his protection stopped Pétya.
The cannon firing was still proceeding when officers came running out of the Cathedral.
Generals came running out of the Cathedral.
Gentlemen-in-waiting came running out of the Cathedral.
Others came running out of the Cathedral in a more leisurely manner.
Caps were raised again.
Those who had run to look at the cannon ran back again.
Four men in uniforms and sashes emerged from the Cathedral doors.
The crowd shouted "Hurrah! hurrah!".
Pétya asked "Which is he? Which?" in a tearful voice.
No one answered Pétya.
Everybody was too excited.
Pétya fixed his gaze on one of the four men.
Pétya could not clearly see the man because of tears of joy.
Pétya concentrated all his enthusiasm on that man.
The man was not the Emperor.
Pétya frantically shouted "Hurrah!".
Pétya resolved that tomorrow, come what might, he would join the army.
The crowd ran after the Emperor.
The crowd followed the Emperor to the palace.
The crowd began to disperse.
It was already late.
Pétya had not eaten anything.
Pétya was drenched with perspiration.
Pétya did not go home.
Pétya stood with the diminishing but still considerable crowd before the palace.
The Emperor was dining.
The Emperor looked in at the palace windows.
The Emperor was looking in at the palace windows, uncertain about what was happening.
The Emperor envied the notables he saw arriving at the entrance to dine with him.
The Emperor envied the court footmen who served at the table.
The court footmen could be seen through the palace windows.
Valúev was looking out of the window.
Valúev said that the people were still hoping to see the Emperor again.
The dinner was nearly over.
The Emperor was munching a biscuit.
The Emperor rose.
The Emperor went out onto the balcony.
The people rushed toward the balcony.
Pétya was among the people rushing toward the balcony.
The crowd cried "Angel! Dear one! Hurrah! Father!...".
Pétya cried with the crowd.
Women and men of weaker mold cried with joy.
Pétya was among the women and men of weaker mold.
A largish piece of the biscuit the Emperor was holding broke off.
The biscuit piece fell on the balcony parapet.
The biscuit piece fell to the ground.
A coachman in a jerkin stood nearest.
The coachman sprang forward.
The coachman snatched the biscuit piece up.
Several people in the crowd rushed at the coachman.
The Emperor had a plateful of biscuits brought to him.
The Emperor began throwing biscuits down from the balcony.
Pétya's eyes grew bloodshot.
Pétya was still more excited by the danger of being crushed.
Pétya rushed at the biscuits.
Pétya did not know why he rushed at the biscuits.
Pétya had to have a biscuit from the Emperor's hand.
Pétya felt that he must not give way.
Pétya sprang forward.
Pétya upset an old woman who was catching at a biscuit.
The old woman was lying on the ground.
The old woman was catching at some biscuits.
The old woman's hand did not reach the biscuits.
Pétya pushed the old woman's hand away with his knee.
Pétya seized a biscuit.
Pétya feared to be too late.
Pétya again shouted "Hurrah!" with a hoarse voice.
The Emperor went in.
After that the greater part of the crowd began to disperse.
